Article Unveiling the multiple effects of MOF-derived TiO2 on Ti-Fe2O3 photoanodes for efficient and stable photoelectrochemical water oxidation Kaikai Ba a Yuʼnan Liu a Kai Zhang a Ping Wang b Yanhong Lin a Dejun Wang a Ziheng Li c Tengfeng Xie a * a College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China College of Chemistry Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China College of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China b Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Material of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Jilin Normal University, Changchun 130103, Jilin, China Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Material of the Ministry of Education College of Chemistry Jilin Normal University Changchun Jilin 130103 China Key Laboratory of Preparation and Applications of Environmental Friendly Material of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry, Jilin Normal University, Changchun 130103, Jilin, China c Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries, College of Physics, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries College of Physics Jilin University Changchun Jilin 130012 China Key Laboratory of Physics and Technology for Advanced Batteries, College of Physics, Jilin University, Changchun 130012, Jilin, China * Corresponding author. α-Fe2O3 is a promising photoanode that is limited by its high surface charge recombination and slow water oxidation kinetics. In this study, we synthesized a TiO2 layer on Ti-Fe2O3 by annealing Ti-MOFs, followed by ZIF-67 as a co-catalyst, to fabricate a ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode for photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting. The systematic experimental and theoretical results revealed that the improvement in performance was due to multiple effects of the MOF-derived TiO2. This molecule not only passivates the acceptor surface states of Ti-Fe2O3, thereby reducing the number of surface recombination centers, but also acts as an electron barrier to promote charge separation in the Ti-Fe2O3 bulk. Moreover, MOF-derived TiO2 can dramatically reduce the energy barrier for the OER of Ti-Fe2O3, thus promoting the conversion of the intermediate *OH into *O. The synergistic improvement in the bulk and surface properties effectively enhanced the water oxidation performance of Ti-Fe2O3. The ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode exhibits a photocurrent density of up to 4.04 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is 9.4 times as that of pure Ti-Fe2O3, and has long-term stability. Our work provides a feasible strategy for constructing efficient organic-inorganic hybrid photoelectrodes. Graphical Abstract The MOF-derived TiO2 not only passivates the acceptor surface states of Ti-Fe2O3 but also functions as an electron barrier layer, thus promoting charge separation in bulk Ti-Fe2O3. Keywords Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode Charge separation Porous TiO2 Multiple effects Water oxidation 1 Introduction Photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting is an ideal solution to deal with the increasingly serious challenges of environmental pollution and energy shortages, as it can convert solar energy into sustainable and clean hydrogen fuel [1–9]. The oxygen evolution reaction is the speed-controlling step in the entire process; therefore, the quality of the photoanode ultimately determines the conversion efficiency of solar energy to hydrogen. Among various photoanode materials for water oxidation, α-Fe2O3 is a particularly attractive semiconductor owing to its good chemical stability, suitable bandgap (2.1 eV), non-toxicity, abundant quantity, and low cost [10]. However, the practical application of α-Fe2O3 in photoelectrochemical water splitting is still limited owing to its rich acceptor surface states and slow water oxidation kinetics. Therefore, it is necessary to perform surface engineering design on α-Fe2O3 to improve its water oxidation efficiency. The abundant acceptor surface states on α-Fe2O3 preferentially capture electrons and thus greatly recombine with holes reaching the surface, resulting in less efficient hole injection [11]. Inhibition of the surface state density by coating with a surface passivation layer has been reported to promote charge transfer between the photoanode and electrolyte, resulting in higher PEC performance. Currently, the passivation layer used in PEC systems is mainly composed of metal oxides such as alumina [12], titanium dioxide [13], NiO x [14], and SnO x [15]. However, the compact and non-stretchable growth of these traditional passivation layers often increases the hole diffusion distance. In recent years, research has mainly focused on the matrix and morphology of cocatalysts, while the study of the inherent α-Fe2O3 environment is often overlooked. Therefore, designing the intrinsic environment of the passivation layer is another way to establish an efficient PEC configuration. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are organic-inorganic hybrid materials that exhibit the bonding structure of metal ions and ligands and have attracted wide attention in catalytic reactions, sensors, and gas storage [16]. Recently, MOFs have been recognized as ideal precursors or templates for the preparation of porous metal oxides, carbon materials, and metal phosphides, mainly because of their ultra-large surface areas, porous structures, and extraordinary thermal and chemical stabilities. Fan et al. [17] utilized highly tunable MOF templates to synthesize 3D open porous-channel electrocatalysts (N-CoP x /Ni2P) that could expose more catalytically active sites. Zhang et al. [18] found that heterojunction cocatalysts derived from Co-MOFs had a stronger promoting effect on the surface reactions of BiVO4 than that of pure MOFs. Xiao et al. [19] prepared porous CdS/CdO-M photoanodes by calcining Cd-MOFs, in which the heterojunctions and pores promoted charge transfer and separation. Inspired by this, the passivation layer of porous metal oxides derived from MOFs is expected to be more conducive to charge and mass transfer between the photoanode and the reactants, which may improve the PEC water oxidation performance. However, there has been limited research on the specific roles of MOF derivatives in PEC water oxidation. Oxygen evolution cocatalysts are commonly used to improve the surface reaction kinetics of photoanodes. Zeolite imidazolate frame-67 (ZIF-67) is an excellent MOF-based cocatalyst for accelerating water oxidation because of its numerous highly active cobalt centers and large surface area [20]. Therefore, the effective construction of organic-inorganic hybrid photoelectrodes will provide a convenient method to solve the inherent defects of the photoanode and promote efficient water splitting. In this study, we first synthesized a Ti-MOF-derived porous TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode using a simple two-step method and then loaded active site-rich ZIF-67 onto TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 as a cocatalyst to promote PEC water oxidation. The ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 composite photoanode demonstrated excellent incident photon-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) and long-term stability, with a photocurrent density of up to 4.04 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is 9.3 times that of pure Ti-Fe2O3. Further studies have revealed the multiple effects of MOF-derived TiO2, which acts as a passivation layer to suppress the recombination center and serves as an effective electron barrier layer to accelerate the charge separation of Ti-Fe2O3 in the bulk; its porous structure can also increase the reaction area. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of Ti-Fe2O3 The Ti-Fe2O3 film was synthesized using a previously reported method with minor modifications [21]. In detail, 20 mL of a homogeneous solution consisting of 0.15 mol L−1 FeCl3, 1 mol L−1 NaNO3, and 30 μL of 0.05% TiCl4 ethanol solution was prepared while stirring. The FTO glass (1 cm × 2.5 cm) was ultrasonically cleaned sequentially in ethanol, acetone, and ethyl acetate. Then, the solution and glass were transferred to a 50 mL polytetrafluoroethylene reactor and heated at 100 °C for 10 h. After the reaction, the electrodes were removed and thoroughly cleaned. Finally, the electrode was annealed at 550 °C for 2 h to obtain the Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3 was synthesized using a hydrothermal method. Before the reaction, Ti-Fe2O3 was treated in an N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution containing polyvinylpyrrolidone (0.2 mmol L−1) for 3 h. Then, 1.0 g of terephthalic acid was dissolved in 18 mL of DMF). Subsequently, 2 mL of methanol and 0.4 mL of butyl titanate were added, and the mixture was stirred for 15 min to obtain a transparent solution. The treated Ti-Fe2O3 and mixed solution were transferred to a 50 mL reactor and heated at 150 °C for 10 h. After cooling, Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3 was rinsed three times with methanol and DMF and placed in a vacuum drying oven at 60 °C for 8 h. The Ti-MOF powder in the reactor was collected as a backup. To obtain TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3 was annealed at 500 °C in a muffle furnace for 2 h. 2.1.3 Synthesis of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 To prepare the precursor solution of ZIF-67, 2.45 g of 2-methylimidazole and 0.38 g of cobalt acetate were dissolved in deionized water (30 mL). Afterwards, the mixed solution was heated at 120 °C for 30 min. The product was centrifuged, washed twice with ethanol, and then dried for 8 h at 60 °C. The prepared ZIF-67 powder (2 mg) was dissolved in 2 mL of ethanol and sonicated in distilled water for 30 min to obtain a drop-casting solution. 15 μL of the mixed solution was cast dropwise onto a 1 cm2 area of the TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode. Finally, the electrode was dried at 120 °C for 1 h to obtain the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 composite photoanode. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed with Cu Kα radiation on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE (λ = 0.15405 nm, 40 KV, 40 mA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using Escalab 250Xi (Al Kα , 1486.6 eV) and contaminated carbon (C 1s, 284.8 eV) was used for binding energy correction. The top morphologies of all samples were obtained by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (HITACHI, Regulus 8100) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectra were recorded on a spectrometer (SHIMADZU UV-3600). Raman spectroscopy was performed using a Renishaw instrument (λ excit = 532 nm). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was performed using a Thermo Fisher Scientific spectrometer (Nicolet 6700). The work function was tested using a Kelvin probe (SKP5050, KP Technology Ltd., Scotland, UK). Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were obtained using a fluorescence spectrometer with an excitation wavelength of 400 nm (FLS920, Edinburgh Instruments). Photoacoustic spectroscopy testing involves the modulation of monochromatic light emitted from a 500 W xenon lamp (CHF-XM500, Beijing Changtuo Technology Co., Ltd.) passing through a monochromator and chopper, which is then focused by a lens and irradiated into a photoacoustic cell. The signal is then converted into a current signal through a current-voltage conversion device and captured by a phase-locked amplifier. An Nd: YAG laser (Q-mart 450, Quantel) was used for transient surface photovoltage spectrum (TPV) testing. The photovoltage signal was amplified using a preamplifier (5003, Brookdeal Electronics) and recorded using a 500 MHz oscilloscope (TDS5054, Tektronix). The steady-state surface photovoltage (SPV) testing system utilized a 500 W xenon lamp (CHF-XM500, Beijing Changtuo Technology Co., Ltd.), monochromator (SBP500, Beijing Zhuolihanguang Instrument Co., Ltd.), chopper, lens, and phase-locked amplifier (SR830, Stanford Research Systems, Inc.). A Helios pump/probe setup (Ultrafast Systems LLC) was used to perform transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy. Laser pulses at 800 nm were generated using an amplifier (Coherent Libra, 50 fs, 1 kHz). In addition, a 3 mm sapphire crystal was used to produce a white light continuum probe and a BBO crystal with a frequency doubling of 800 nm was used to produce 400 nm pump pulses. The diameter of the pump beam spot was 2 mm, the pump power was 30 μW, and the probe beam was 50 μm. The probe beam that passed through the sample was collected using a UV-vis detector (CCD sensor). The charge lifetimes of the samples were characterized using time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL, FLS1000, Edinburgh). 2.3 PEC Measurements A three-electrode system equipped with an electrochemical station (CHI-660E) was used for the electrochemical tests, in which a photoanode, saturated Ag/AgCl electrode, and Pt electrode were used as the working, reference, and counter electrodes, respectively. Unless otherwise specified, the electrolyte was a 1 mol L−1 KOH solution (pH 13.6) and the reaction area of the working electrode was 0.283 square centimeters. The 300 W xenon lamp (Micro Solar 300 Perfect Light) was used as a light source, and the incident light intensity was measured using a digital radiometer (FZ-A, Beijing Normal University Optoelectronic Instrument Factory) with a cosine characteristic (directional response) error of 4% (irradiance measurement range: 0.1–200000 μW cm−2). The specific parameters for photoelectrochemical testing can be found in the Supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization Scheme 1 shows the synthesis of the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanodes. The Ti-Fe2O3 nanorod array was prepared based on a previously reported method, where the introduction of titanium dopants aimed to improve the conductivity. Subsequently, Ti-MOFs were coated in situ on Ti-Fe2O3 using a hydrothermal method, which was used as a template for annealing to form a rough and porous TiO2 layer. Finally, ZIF-67 was dispersed on the surface of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, further promoting the hole transfer from Ti-Fe2O3 to the electrolyte. The morphologies of the photoanodes were observed by SEM and TEM. The pure Ti-Fe2O3 arrays were composed of nanorods approximately 50 nm in diameter, and the thickness of the array was 525 nm (Fig. 1(a) and Fig. S1). After the growth of Ti-MOFs, as shown in Fig. 1(b), the Ti-Fe2O3 surface became significantly rougher, and its diameter increased to approximately 70 nm. After annealing, Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3 transformed into porous TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, and the diameter of the nanorods was approximately 55 nm (Fig. 1(c)). After the purple suspension was dropped onto TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, the synthesized ZIF-67 exhibited a regular rhombic dodecahedral shape with a size of approximately 2 μm (Fig. 1(d) and Fig. S2). Subsequently, an approximately 5 nm-thick TiO2 layer was observed on Ti-Fe2O3 by TEM (Fig. 1(e) and Fig. S3). The lattice spacing of 0.25 and 0.24 nm in the HRTEM image corresponded to the (110) plane of α-Fe2O3 and the (004) plane of anatase TiO2 (Fig. 1(f)), respectively [22,23]. In Fig. 1(g), an even distribution of elements (Fe, Ti, and O) on the nanorods were observed through HRTEM energy spectrum mapping, indicating the successful preparation of the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode. The crystal phase compositions of the photoanodes were determined from the XRD patterns. In Fig. 2(a) , two characteristic peaks of the photoanodes appeared at 35.6° and 63.9°, corresponding to the (110) and (300) planes of the α-Fe2O3 phase (PDF # 33-0664), respectively. Subsequently, a new diffraction peak (6.7°) appeared in the XRD pattern of Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3, which is in accordance with the main diffraction peak of typical MIL-125(Ti) (Fig. S4(a)) [24]. Owing to the low ZIF-67 content, the characteristic peak was not easily observed (Fig. S4(b)). When Ti-MOF/Ti-Fe2O3 was completely converted into TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, the characteristic peaks of the Ti-MOFs disappeared. Owing to an insufficient load or the influence of the FTO substrate, the characteristic peaks of TiO2 were not detected for TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3. However, we obtained TiO2 powder consisting of anatase and rutile phases by annealing the collected Ti-MOFs, which is consistent with a previous report [25]. In addition, the crystal structures of the photoanodes were analyzed using Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2(b)). For Ti-Fe2O3, the vibration bands at 294, 410, 612, and 660 cm−1 are designated as the E 1g mode, those at 227 and 500 cm−1 belong to the A1g mode, and the peak at 1316 cm−1 originates from second-order Raman scattering [26]. Moreover, the E 1g peaks of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 and ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 exhibited a slight negative shift at 660 cm−1, indicating that the local crystal structure of Ti-Fe2O3 may be affected by the loading of TiO2 and ZIF-67. To confirm the successful preparation of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, FT-IR spectroscopy was used to detect the presence of functional groups (Fig. 2(c)). The broad peaks at approximately 3420 cm−1 correspond to the absorption peak of O–H. Specifically, the stretching vibrations of the imidazole ring were observed at 1018, 1302, and 1454 cm−1, while the peak at 1585 cm−1 was attributed to the C=N stretching mode [27]. The peaks of all photoanodes around 544 cm−1 were designated as characteristic stretching vibrations of the Fe−O bond. The porous properties of Ti-MOFs and MOF-derived TiO2 were evaluated using N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at −196.15 °C and pore size distribution curves (Fig. 2(d) and Fig. S4(c)). The prepared Ti-MOFs exhibited a typical Type I curve, indicating a microporous structure (inset in Fig. S4(c)) [28]. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the obtained Ti-MOFs was 1729 m2 g−1, which is similar to that of previously reported Ti-MOFs. After calcination at 500 °C, Ti-MOFs decomposed into TiO2 with a sharp decrease in surface area. However, the MOF-derived TiO2 still exhibited a good BET surface area (45.5 m2 g−1), which improves the contact surface area with the electrolyte and facilitates the mass transfer process during PEC water oxidation. To investigate the effect of TiO2 derived from MOFs on the water adsorption capacity, the differences in hydrophilicity between Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 were compared using contact angle measurements. From Fig. 2(e), the average contact angle between Ti-Fe2O3 and distilled water was approximately 72° and the average contact angle of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was 34°. The significant reduction in the contact angle indicates that the surface roughness makes TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 more hydrophilic, which is attributed to the expansion of its active surface area. From the UV-vis absorption spectrum (Fig. 2(f)), it can be observed that, compared with Ti-Fe2O3, the absorption band edges of the other photoanodes have a slight red shift, which means that the porous structure may effectively improve light capture in the photoanode, thus increasing the probability of photon capture. The elemental composition and valence states of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 were investigated using XPS. The XPS peaks of six elements (Fe, Ti, O, Co, N, and C) were confirmed for the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode (Fig. 3(a) and Fig. S4(d) ). From Fig. 3(b), the peaks at 710.82 and 724.18 eV correspond to Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2, respectively [29]. In Fig. 3(c), the peaks at 458.09 and 463.83 eV correspond to Ti 2p 3/2 and Ti 2p 1/2, respectively, indicating the presence of Ti4+ states in TiO2 [30]. The O 1s peak can be divided into two peaks (Fig. 3(d)): hydroxyl oxygen (531.4 eV) and lattice oxygen (529.5 eV) [31]. In Fig. 3(e), the Co 2p spectrum of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 can be deconvoluted into two different peaks corresponding to Co 2p 1/2 and Co 2p 3/2 followed by satellite peaks (Sat.). This indicates that Co exists mainly in the positive divalent state [32]. Simultaneously, the N 1s spectrum of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (Fig. 3(f)) was deconvoluted into two peaks: Co-N (399.5 eV) and pyrrole N (400.46 eV) [33]. The results of the XPS spectra mentioned above suggest the formation of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3. 3.2 PEC properties of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanodes The PEC performance of the obtained photoanodes was measured using linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) under AM 1.5 G illumination in 1 mol L−1 KOH. As shown in Fig. 4(a) , the photocurrent density of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 at 1.23 V vs. RHE reached 3.0 mA cm−2 and the onset potential shifted cathodically by 100 mV, indicating that the porous TiO2 passivation layer reduced surface charge recombination and enhanced the driving force of the water oxidation reaction. Subsequently, the performances of the composite photoanodes were optimized by drop-casting ZIF-67 at different concentrations (Fig. S5), and the photocurrent density of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 significantly increased to 4.04 mA cm−2, which is 9.3 times that of pure Ti-Fe2O3, exceeding that of most Fe2O3-based photoanodes (Table 1 ). From the LSV curves for samples tested in the dark, it can be seen that ZIF-67 exhibits good electrocatalytic performance. Furthermore, the light conversion efficiency was investigated through an incident photon-current efficiency (IPCE) test (Fig. 4(b)); the IPCE value of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 at 390 nm was approximately 93%, indicating that the composite photoanode can more effectively utilize the absorbed light [34]. The absorption photon current conversion efficiency (APCE) of the composite photoanode at 390 nm was 94% (Fig. S6). Simultaneously, ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (0.52%) achieved a higher ABPE value than pure Ti-Fe2O3 (0.04%) at a lower bias (Fig. 4(c)). These results indicate that the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode has superior solar energy conversion efficiency. Subsequently, a photostability test was conducted on ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 at 1.23 V vs. RHE under AM 1.5G illumination (Fig. 4(d)). After working for 40 h, ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 maintained nearly 90% of its initial photocurrent, indicating that the composite photoanode had remarkable stability. To comprehensively explore the photogenerated charge separation and transfer behavior of the photoanodes, we first characterized the charge separation efficiency using steady-state SPV based on the lock-in-amplifier. Generally, the efficiency of charge separation is directly proportional to the intensity of the photovoltage, where a positive signal indicates the migration of separated holes towards the sample surface and a negative signal represents the accumulation of electrons on the surface [50]. Fig. S7 shows that the SPV response of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was significantly stronger than that of Ti-Fe2O3 in the range 300–800 nm, indicating that after the surface state was passivated, the recombination centers decreased, and charge separation was significantly enhanced. After loading the cocatalyst, the photovoltage signal was further enhanced, revealing that ZIF-67 had a good hole collection ability. To further study the dynamic behavior of the charges, transient surface photovoltage (TPV) tests were conducted [51]. Fig. 5(a) shows that ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 exhibited the highest TPV response, further demonstrating the high charge-separation efficiency of the composite photoanode. Significantly, the negative signal appearing at Peak 1 (1.03 × 10−7 s) of Ti-Fe2O3 before reaching Peak 2 (4.37 × 10−7 s) was caused by the acceptor surface state (Fig. 5(b)), while the negative signal of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 disappeared significantly, indicating that porous TiO2 can effectively passivate the acceptor surface state of pure Ti-Fe2O3. Benefiting from the slow recombination and rapid transport of holes, the surface of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 accumulated more photogenerated holes, waiting to react with H2O. To investigate the driving force of hole transfer, we measured the work function (WF) values of Ti-Fe2O3 and MOF-derived TiO2 using Kelvin probe technology [52]. Fig. 5(c) shows the contact potential difference (∆CPD) between the sample and the Au probe; the calculated WF values of Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2 were 4.64 and 4.91 eV, respectively, indicating that the Fermi energy level of Ti-Fe2O3 is higher than that of TiO2. When the MOF-derived TiO2 was deposited in situ on Ti-Fe2O3, an interfacial electric field from Ti-Fe2O3 to TiO2 was formed, which was beneficial for the flow of photogenerated electrons towards the FTO substrate (Fig. S8). Fig. 5(d) shows the open-circuit potentials (OCP) of the photoanodes under dark and illuminated conditions. The differences in the OCPs (∆OCP) were Ti-Fe2O3 (0.14 V), TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (0.18 V), and ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (0.2 V), indicating that the introduction of porous TiO2 and ZIF-67 produces a strong interfacial electric field at the solid-liquid interface. It is worth noting that in the dark, TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 had a more positive OCP (0.81 V vs. RHE) that exhibited a more obvious upward band bending owing to the passivation of the surface states of Ti-Fe2O3 to unpin the Fermi level. In Fig. 5(e), the PL signal of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was much higher than that of Ti-Fe2O3 because the nonradiative recombination of excitons on the surface of Ti-Fe2O3 depends on surface defects [53]. When the acceptor surface state is partially passivated by the TiO2 layer, nonradiative recombination weakens, and radiative recombination strengthens. Non-radiative recombination on the surface of Ti-Fe2O3 was measured by photoacoustic spectroscopy (PA), as shown in Fig. 5(f), and the PA signal of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was significantly lower than that of Ti-Fe2O3. Therefore, the passivation of the surface states can significantly improve the charge-separation efficiency of Ti-Fe2O3. To gain a deeper understanding of the dynamics of charge carriers in the MOF-derived TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 composite photoanode, we performed ultrafast transient absorption (TA) spectroscopy under excitation at 400 nm. Fig. 6(a) shows the photogenerated absorption (PA) spectra of Ti-Fe2O3 at different probe delays. Based on previous investigations, we focused on analyzing the evolution of PA within the wavelength range 545–750 nm to investigate the hole transfer process in TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 [54,55]. As illustrated in Figs. 6(a) and 6(b), a broad positive absorption band was observed for both Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, mainly owing to excited-state absorption. Compared with pure Ti-Fe2O3, the more intense positive signal of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 suggests that the presence of a passivation layer and an electron barrier layer can separate more photogenerated holes. In addition, double-exponential fitting was suitable for the TAS decay curve probed at 625 nm to study the decay kinetics of the holes. Generally, the short lifetime (τ 1) and long lifetime (τ 2) components result from holes trapped at shallow and deep sites before their recombination. In Figs. 6(c) and 7(d), compared to pure Ti-Fe2O3 (τ 1: 0.22 ± 0.03 ps; τ 2: 21.76 ± 6.45 ps), the decay lifetimes of the TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode largely decreased to (0.20 ± 0.02 ps) and (13.05 ± 3.97 ps). Interestingly, loading MOF-derived TiO2 onto Ti-Fe2O3 had little effect on τ 1 but significantly altered τ 2. This change can be attributed to the effect of the interfacial electric field; the MOF-derived TiO2 acts as a barrier layer, causing the electrons of Ti-Fe2O3 to rapidly migrate towards the bulk phase, while the holes migrate to the surface, achieving the spatial separation of charge carriers. Additionally, TRPL decay spectra (Fig. S9) were obtained to further study the dynamics of the photogenerated charge carriers. Herein, the fast lifetime (τ 1) of the samples decreased from 0.42 to 0.32 ns when TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was formed, and the slow lifetime (τ 2) of the TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode drastically decreased from 4.34 to 4.12 ns (double exponential fitting is suitable for the PL decay curve probed at 470 nm). These results fully explain that the introduction of MOF-derived TiO2 to Ti-Fe2O3 can effectively improve the charge separation efficiency. As shown in Fig. 7(a) , the photoresponse ability of the photoanodes was studied using the J-t curves under chopping light, which is also considered an effective method for studying the surface hole accumulation process of photoanodes [56]. Interestingly, the anode peaks of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 disappeared and showed nearly rectangular and stable photocurrents, indicating that surface charge recombination was suppressed and hole injection was smoother. Moreover, we integrated the transient anode current peaks at different potentials to determine the accumulated charges (Fig. 7(b)). The accumulated charge of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was significantly higher than that of Ti-Fe2O3 at low potentials (< 0.8 VRHE), implying that the hole was efficiently transmitted and was positively correlated with the separation efficiency. Subsequently, the accumulated charge of pure Ti-Fe2O3 gradually exceeded that of the other photoanodes as the applied potential increased (0.8–1.6 VRHE), indicating that its slow water oxidation kinetics led to the inability of holes to be transferred in a timely manner [57]. In addition, the charge injection efficiency (η inj) and separation efficiency (η sep) of the photoanodes were evaluated in KOH with and without the hole sacrificial agent (H2O2), and the obtained LSV curves are shown in Fig. S10. The η inj of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 reached 91% at 1.23 V vs. RHE in Fig. 7(c), which confirms the influence of porous TiO2 in effectively reducing surface defects, increasing the solid-liquid reaction area, and accelerating hole transport. The η sep is obtained based on the light collection efficiency (LHE) and integrated current density (J abs) (Fig. S11) [58]. The η sep of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (40.7% at 1.23 V vs. RHE) was also significantly higher than those of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (34.4%) and pure Ti-Fe2O3 (29.1%) in Fig. S12, which agrees with the analysis of the surface photovoltage spectrum. To further study the charge transfer process between the photoanode and electrolyte, Nyquist plots were obtained in 1 mol L−1 KOH. The arc radius of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was smaller in the low-frequency regions than those of the other three photoanodes (Fig. 7(d)), indicating that multifunctional porous TiO2 can effectively promote hole transport and injection. Subsequently, the Nyquist plots were fitted using an equivalent circuit (Table S1), where R s, R 1, and R 2 represent the series resistance, bulk resistance, and solid-liquid interface resistance, respectively, and CPE represents the corresponding capacitor components [59]. From the fitting results, the R 2 value of the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode (340.5 Ω) was the smallest, which agrees with the previous η inj. It should be noted that the R 1 (47.85 Ω) and R 2 (720.8 Ω) values of photogenerated holes within the TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode were significantly lower than those of Ti-Fe2O3 (131.8 and 3154 Ω), confirming that TiO2 can improve the hole transport process of the surface owing to its large surface area (Fig. 7(e)) [60]. The oxygen production kinetics of the photoanodes were studied using the Bode phase plots in Fig. 8(a) . The peak of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 in the low-frequency region shifted significantly towards higher frequencies, indicating that its oxygen production kinetics were faster [61]. Figs. 8(b) and 8(c) show the R 1, R 2, and potential curves in the range 0.8–1.5 VRHE. Specifically, the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode exhibited a relatively low R 1 value in the range 0.8–1.3 VRHE. Subsequently, we determined the charge transfer efficiency (η CT) based on the method reported by Monllor Satoca et al. [62]: η C T = K C T K C T + K t r a p = R 1 R 1 + R 2 where K CT and K trap are the rate constants of charge transfer and recombination, respectively. Fig. 8(d) shows the η CT values at various potentials. The R 2 and η CT values are directly correlated, which means reducing the R 2 value can provide a high charge injection efficiency [63]. The η CT value of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was 87% while that of Ti-Fe2O3 was 29% at 1.23 V vs. RHE, indicating that the holes of the composite photoanode can be quickly transferred to the electrolyte. We also conducted an approximate evaluation of the electrochemically active area (ECSA) of an electrochemical double-layer capacitor (C dl) (Fig. 8(e) and Fig. S13) [64]. In Fig. 8(f), the C dl of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (48.7 mF cm−2) was higher than that of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (36.2 mF cm−2) and Ti-Fe2O3 (24.5 mF cm−2). This result further demonstrates that multifunctional TiO2 increases the solid-liquid reaction area, which is conducive to the transfer process of the reaction, and that the cocatalyst ZIF-67, which is rich in active cobalt sites, can quickly capture holes and synergistically accelerate the water oxidation kinetics of Ti-Fe2O3. A detailed microstructural analysis of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was conducted after 10 h to determine its stability. Figs. S14(a) and 14(b) show that after long-term stability testing, there was no significant change in the surface of the composite photoanode, and the presence of the porous TiO2 layer and ZIF-67 particles were still observed. In Fig. S14(c), Fe, Ti, and O were uniformly distributed on the composite photoanode. The FT-IR spectra (Fig. S14(d)) show that the imidazole ring exhibited tensile vibration at 1100–1500 cm−1 and the corresponding Fe-O bond was observed at 526 cm−1. In addition, the Co3+/Co2+ ratio of Co 2p 3/2 increased significantly after the stability testing (Fig. S14(e)), indicating that ZIF-67 can quickly capture holes from TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3, thereby providing active sites for water oxidation. This study offers good guidance for an in-depth understanding of the role of MOFs and their derivatives in PEC water splitting and for the effective construction of organic-inorganic hybrid photoelectrodes in the future. 3.3 Theoretical simulation and calculation result All density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [65]. The Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) [66] functional was employed to treat the exchange-correlation interactions. The plane-wave basis was set with a kinetic energy cutoff of 400 eV, energy convergence criterion of 10−4 eV, force convergence criterion of 0.02 eV Å−1, and a (1×1×1) Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling was employed for structure relaxation. A sufficiently large vacuum gap (>12 Å) was employed to prevent interactions between neighboring periodic structures. H2 and H2O were calculated in boxes of 20 Å × 20 Å × 20 Å with the gamma point only. In this study, the OER on both the Ti-Fe2O3 (110) and MOF-derived TiO2 (004) surfaces was studied by DFT because the (110) and (004) surfaces match the exposed surface of our prepared film (as shown in Figs. 1(f) and 2(a)). The free-energy diagrams for the OER over Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 were calculated with reference to a computational hydrogen electrode, as shown in Fig. 9 [67]. The free energy of the gas phase and adsorbed species can be obtained from the following equation: ∆G = ∆E DFT + ∆ZPE – T∆S, where T was 25 °C and ∆ZPE and T∆S was the change in the zero-point energy and entropy, respectively. The construction and chemisorption models for Ti-Fe2O3 and TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 are shown in Fig. S15. The four-electron-transfer process during the OER can be divided into four reaction steps that include different intermediates (*OH, *O, and *OOH), representing the active sites of the catalyst). According to the free energy change during the OER for these two photoanodes (Fig. 9), the second step (*OH → *O) of Ti-Fe2O3 that has a large energy barrier (ΔG) of 3.38 eV is the determining step, indicating that the native surface of Ti-Fe2O3 has a poor OER activity. When TiO2 was the passivation layer and electron barrier layer, the fourth step (*OOH → O2) became the determining step with an energy barrier of 1.67 eV, which is significantly lower than that of Ti-Fe2O3, indicating that the OER occurs more easily on TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 surfaces than on Ti-Fe2O3 surfaces, which is consistent with their photocurrent densities (Fig. 4(a)). Therefore, the MOF-derived TiO2 layer provides efficient surface active sites and can dramatically reduce the energy barrier required for the OER and accelerate the reaction kinetics during PEC water splitting. The projected density of states (PDOS) of the three intermediates adsorbed by TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 and Ti-Fe2O3 are shown in Fig. S16. The d-band centers of TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 adsorption for *OH, *O, and *OOH were –2.269, –2.242, and –2.255 eV, respectively, significantly higher than those of bare Ti-Fe2O3 at –2.539, –2.573, and –2.595 eV, indicating that TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 promotes the adsorption of O species [68]. This leads to fewer antibonding states, which enhances the bond strength and accelerates the reaction kinetics [69]. 3.4 Discussion of the enhanced performance mechanism Based on the above results, a possible charge-transfer mechanism for the ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode was proposed (Scheme 2 ). For pure Ti-Fe2O3 as an n-type semiconductor, electron-hole pairs are typically generated by photoanodes through light absorption during the PEC water oxidation process. The photogenerated electrons are excited to the conduction band (CB) and then move towards the cathode through the FTO substrate for water reduction. Meanwhile, photoinduced holes continue to exist in the valence band (VB) and move towards the surface of the photoanode, participating in the water oxidation process. However, owing to the presence of acceptor surface states (SS), the recombination of holes reaching the surface can occur, resulting in a hole quasi-Fermi level (E f,p) that cannot reach the water oxidation potential (Scheme 2(a)). For TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 (Scheme 2(b)), the TiO2 layer obtained using Ti-MOFs as the template makes the surface of Ti-Fe2O3 rougher and more porous, which not only inhibits high surface charge recombination but also increases the solid-liquid reaction area, generating more holes on the photoanode surface to participate in the reaction. It also serves as an effective electron barrier layer that transfers electrons from TiO2 to Ti-Fe2O3 under an electric field, accelerating the charge separation in Ti-Fe2O3. DFT calculations show that the water oxidation energy barrier on the surface of TiO2 is much lower than that on Ti-Fe2O3, further confirming that the active sites of the OER over TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 are located on the surface of TiO2. In addition, the cocatalyst ZIF-67, which is rich in active sites, can quickly capture photogenerated holes and accelerate the transfer of holes from Ti-Fe2O3 to the electrolyte (Scheme 2(c)), thereby reducing the accumulation of holes on the photoanode surface. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully obtained a ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode with excellent water oxidation performance through surface engineering modification of a Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode. The photocurrent density of ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 was as high as 4.04 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, and the IPCE and injection efficiency were 93% (at 390 nm) and 91%, respectively. The significant performance of the composite photoanode is attributed to the multiple effects of MOF-derived TiO2 on Ti-Fe2O3, including passivation of acceptor surface states, increase of solid-liquid contact area, and rapid transfer of charge. The theoretical simulation indicated that the d-band center shifted upward to promote the adsorption/desorption of intermediates, which synergistically enhanced the water oxidation efficiency of Ti-Fe2O3. This study provides a new strategy for the effective construction of organic-inorganic hybrid photoelectrodes. coredata.dc:description: α-Fe2O3 is a promising photoanode that is limited by its high surface charge recombination and slow water oxidation kinetics. In this study, we synthesized a TiO2 layer on Ti-Fe2O3 by annealing Ti-MOFs, followed by ZIF-67 as a co-catalyst, to fabricate a ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode for photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting. The systematic experimental and theoretical results revealed that the improvement in performance was due to multiple effects of the MOF-derived TiO2. This molecule not only passivates the acceptor surface states of Ti-Fe2O3, thereby reducing the number of surface recombination centers, but also acts as an electron barrier to promote charge separation in the Ti-Fe2O3 bulk. Moreover, MOF-derived TiO2 can dramatically reduce the energy barrier for the OER of Ti-Fe2O3, thus promoting the conversion of the intermediate *OH into *O. The synergistic improvement in the bulk and surface properties effectively enhanced the water oxidation performance of Ti-Fe2O3. The ZIF-67/TiO2/Ti-Fe2O3 photoanode exhibits a photocurrent density of up to 4.04 mA cm−2 at 1.23 V vs. RHE, which is 9.4 times as that of pure Ti-Fe2O3, and has long-term stability. Our work provides a feasible strategy for constructing efficient organic-inorganic hybrid photoelectrodes.
